metadata.title: Single-cell atlas of a non-human primate reveals new pathogenic mechanisms of COVID-19 2 3

affiliation.institution: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS)

affiliation.laboratory: Key Laboratory of Single-Cell Omics, BGI-Shenzhen

location.settlement: Cambridge, Cambridge, Shenzhen, Shenzhen, Shenzhen Bay Laboratory, Shenzhen

body_text.text: . To test experimental treatments, 97 animal models close to humans are necessary due to sequence variation of ACE2 and changes 98 in the proportions of cell subtypes in organs between species. For these reasons, it is essential 99 to have a species close to human to study . In this regard, monkey experiments have 100 already shown that reinfection of SARS-CoV-2 is preventable by acquired immunity, thus, 101 largely debunking one of the initial myths about the disease (Bao et al., 2020) . 102

Questions about the proportions of cell types within organs between species and their 103 crosstalk can be addressed effectively through single-cell profiling technologies, in particular 104 single-cell RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) and single-cell assay for transposase accessible 105 chromatin sequencing (ATAC-seq). Yet, although human data are accumulating (Han et al., 106 2020) , monkey data are still scarce. The comparison between human and monkey data will 107 be crucial for advancing our knowledge of COVID-19. 108

Here, we provide a high-resolution single-cell atlas of nine organs/tissues (lung, kidney, 109 pancreas, brain, parotid, liver, thyroid, aorta artery, and blood) in monkey, encompassing 110 215,334 cells. By comparing the expression of SARS related targets in monkey and human, we 111 have identified cell-to-cell similarities as expected. Crucially, we also discovered stark 112 differences in ACE2 expression between these two species, for example in the ciliated vs 113 alveolar type 2 cells of the lung and the hepatocytes in liver. We also observed that ACE2 is 114 heterogeneous among different epithelial cell subtypes across these organs/tissues, 115

suggesting that variations in cell state could influence viral entry. Supporting this, single-cell 116 ATAC-seq of monkey kidney identified regulatory elements driven by STAT transcription 117 factors and interferon regulatory factor (IRF) in the ACE2 locus. This suggests that cytokines, 118 particularly IL6, aiming to induce a tissue protective response can exacerbate the disease by 119 aiding viral entry into target cells. Additionally, through correlation analysis with ACE2 120 expression, we have identified several potential candidates involved in COVID-19 121 pathophysiology, such as Transmembrane protein 27 (TMEM27), Indoleamine 2,3-122 dioxygenase 2 (IDO2), DnaJ heat shock protein family (Hsp40) member C12 (DNAJC12) and 123
Alanyl aminopeptidase N (ANPEP). These targets may offer therapeutic opportunities. 124

Taken together, our data constitute a unique resource which will aid the scientific community 125 in the fight against SARS-CoV-2. From a wider perspective, this will also be useful for 126 comparative studies aimed at understanding physiological differences between monkey and 127 other species, in particular, human. 128 7 acinar cells in cluster 27 and parotid acinar cells in cluster 31 (Fig. 1C, S1C) . We next 161 performed clustering and differential gene expression analysis to dissect the cellular 162 composition of each individual organ. This analysis confirmed the typical patterns of cell 163 heterogeneity for all the organs/tissues. When examining the lung tissue, we defined 10 164 major clusters with specific molecular markers, including ciliated cells, macrophages, 165 fibroblasts, pericytes, alveolar (pneumocytes) type 1 and type 2, endothelial and club cells 166 (Fig. S2A) . The kidney consisted of 11 clusters, those being podocytes, thick ascending limb 167 cell, proximal tubule cells, intercalated cells 1 and 2, connecting tubule cells, distal convoluted 168 tubule cells, stomal cells, thin limb cells, principal cells and endothelial cells (Fig. S2B) . Analysis 169 of liver tissue revealed hepatocytes to be the larger population of cells, while other clusters 170 consisted of cholangiocytes, macrophages (Kupffer cells), natural killer-T (NK-T) cells, 171 endothelial cells and hepatic stellate cells (Fig. S2C ). In agreement with previous data, 172 inspection of PBMC clustering revealed large populations of B cells, CD4 + , CD8 + naïve and CD8 + 173 memory T cells, together with smaller populations of natural killer (NK) cells, dendritic cells, 174 CD16 + and CD14 + monocytes (Fig. S2D) . We clustered the neocortex and found excitatory 175 neurons, astrocytes, microglia, parvalbumin (PVALB), somatostatin-expressing neurons (SST), 176 synaptic vesicle glycoprotein-expressing cells (SV2C), vasoactive intestinal polypeptide-177 expressing neurons (VIP), oligodendrocytes and oligodendrocyte precursor cells (Fig S2E) . 178

Parotid gland instead was composed of a large cluster of serous acinar cells together with 179 small clusters of macrophages, myoepithelial cells, striated duct cells, mucous acinar cells and 180 intercalated duct cells (Fig. S2F) . Aorta cells could be further divided into adipocytes, 181 endothelial cells, myofibroblasts and a large proportion of smooth muscle cells (Fig. S2G) . Our 182 clustering also demonstrated that most of the thyroid gland is composed of follicular cells, 183 with smaller populations of adipocytes, endothelial cells, stromal and smooth muscle cells 184 (Fig. S2H) . Finally, our data showed the largest population of the pancreas to be acinar cells, 185 while smaller clusters were comprised of macrophages, ductal, alpha and beta cells (Fig. S2I) . 186

In conclusion, we have successfully profiled the transcriptome of nine organs at a single-cell 187 resolution in monkey, which could assist in the study of COVID-19. 188 189 ACE2 and TMPRSS2 single-cell expression landscape in a non-human primate 190 8 al., 2020; Walls et al., 2020), which is involved in the control of blood pressure through the 193 renin-angiotensin system (Turner et al., 2004) . This phenomenon is primed by the 194 multifunction serine protease TMPRSS2 (Kim et al., 2006) . Accordingly, double positive 195 (ACE2 + /TMPRSS2 + ) cells have a higher risk of infection by SARS-CoV-2. Although 196 immunohistological studies have demonstrated localization of these two proteins in the 197 respiratory tract (Jia et al., 2005) , it is unclear how many cell subtypes express these genes 198 and how homogenous the expression among a specific cell subtype is. Also, comprehensive 199 information about other cell types and organs that express these two proteins and could be 200 targeted by the virus in human or monkey is lacking. 201

We inspected our data to see how widespread and homogenous ACE2 expression was in the 202 monkey tissues. As expected, ACE2 was detected in several lung clusters, such as ciliated cells, 203 club cells and pulmonary alveolar type 2 cells ( Fig. 2A, 3A upper panel) . In the kidney, ACE2 204 was primarily present in proximal tubule cells, though interestingly, the expression was 205 heterogenous ( Fig. 2A, 3B upper panel) . This is consistent with reports that a significant 206 number of COVID-19 patients display altered kidney function Naicker et al., 207 2020 ). In the liver, ACE2 was mostly expressed in cholangiocytes, with a smaller degree of 208 expression also found in hepatocytes ( Fig. 2A, 3C upper panel) . Notably, the closely related 209 SARS-CoV caused liver injury due to hepatitis in some patients (Peiris et al., 2003) , suggesting 210 that the liver may also be a direct target for SARS-CoV-2. Likewise, ACE2 was detected in 211 follicular cells within the thyroid tissue (Fig. S3) . In contrast, little or no expression was 212 observed in neocortex, pancreas, parotid and PBMC ( Fig. 2A, S3A) . 213

On the other hand, TMPRSS2 displayed widespread expression across multiple tissues, 214 although it was highest in kidney cells. However, in contrast to ACE2, its expression was 215 highest in the distal convoluted tubule, thin limb, intercalated and principal cell 1 and 2 kidney 216 clusters (Fig. 2B, 3B lower panel, S3B) . Additionally, significant TMPRSS2 was observed in 217 both parotid and pancreatic acinar cells, follicular cells and in several lung clusters (Fig. 2B) . 218 We then determined which cells co-expressed both genes (ACE2 + /TMPRSS2 + ). The largest 219 overlap was observed in the ciliated and club cell clusters of the lung and the proximal tubule 220 cells of the kidney. A smaller overlap was observed in hepatocytes and pancreatic cells (Fig.  221   2C Given the heterogeneous nature of ACE2 and TMPRSS2 expression in monkey tissues, we 231 decided to investigate similarities and differences between human and monkey. For this 232 purpose, we retrieved publicly available data from single-cell studies in human (see methods). 233 TMPRSS2 distribution was similar in cell subtypes of lung, kidney and liver between human 234 and monkey ( Fig. 3D-3F) . However, strikingly, ACE2 showed distinct patterns among cell 235 subtypes in all three organs between the two species ( Fig. 3D-3F) . The biggest differences 236 were observed in ciliated cells of the lung, which had the highest expression of ACE2 in 237 monkey, and pulmonary alveolar type 2 cells, which had the highest expression of ACE2 in 238 human. The function of ciliated cells is to move substances (e.g. cell debris and toxic material) 239 across the surface of the respiratory tract and are commonly targeted by respiratory viruses, 240 whereas pulmonary alveolar type 2 cells have regenerative properties, are crucial for alveolar 241 homeostasis and produce surfactant (Hamm et al., 1992; Mason and Williams, 1977) . In the 242 kidney of both monkey and human, the highest ACE2 expression was in proximal tubule cells 243 ( Fig. 3E) , which are responsible for electrolyte and nutrient reabsorption. However, renal 244 endothelial cells had higher expression in monkey compared to human. In liver, 245 cholangiocytes had similarly high ACE2 expression in monkey and human, but hepatocytes 246 showed higher expression and more positive cells in the human (Fig. 3F) . After discovering 247 heterogenous expression of ACE2 within the proximal tubule cells, we revisited the previously 248 analyzed data and were able to sub cluster this population of cells into two (S1 and S3) based The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.022103 doi: bioRxiv preprint These differences in ACE2 expression across cell subtypes in the lung, kidney and liver in 256 monkey and human raise the possibility that infection with SARS-CoV-2 in the two species will 257 have different effects. 258 259 ACE2 correlation analysis across cell types reveals potentially therapeutic targets 260

To shed light on potential mechanisms that could facilitate ACE2-mediated SARS-CoV-2 261 infection, we performed an analysis of the Pearson's correlation coefficient, based on gene 262 expression in the 44 cell subtypes, to determine what genes are co-regulated with ACE2 in 263 monkey tissues. Correlated genes were considered as those displaying a coefficient higher 264 than 0.6 with an adjusted p-value < 0.001. Using these criteria, we observed several genes 265 with marked correlation, including genes that belong to metabolic and developmental 266 pathways and genes involved in the cellular response to xenobiotic stimuli (Fig. 4A, B) . The to mediate inflammatory autoimmunity (Ball et al., 2009; Lepiller et al., 2015) . ANPEP, which 277 encodes for alanyl aminopeptidase N, was also co-expressed with ACE2 in kidney, liver and to 278 a lesser extent in lung too (cor = 0.64), like IDO2 (Fig. 4C, D) . Interestingly, ANPEP has also 279 been shown to be participate in immune responses, virus receptor activity and in mediating 280 virus entry into host cells (Delmas et al., 1992; Wentworth and Holmes, 2001) . The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.022103 doi: bioRxiv preprint

To understand whether epigenetic mechanisms underlie the heterogeneity of cellular 289 composition and cell state variation in the kidney, we employed DNBelab C4 technology to 290 perform high-throughput single-cell ATAC-seq (Fig. 5A) . After filtering, 6,353 nuclei were used 291 for downstream analysis (Supplemental table 4, Fig. S5A, B) . We integrated these data with 292 the kidney transcriptomic data described in Fig. 1 and proceeded to perform Louvain 293 clustering to map all the different cell types within the dataset (Fig. 5B) . Consistent with the 294 transcriptomic data, our epigenomic mapping identified thick ascending limb cells and 295 proximal tubule cells as the largest kidney clusters (Fig. S2B) . Similarly, smaller clusters of 296 podocytes, principal, intercalated, connected tubule, distal convoluted tubule, thin limb, 297 endothelial and stromal cells were detected (Fig. 5C, S5C) . Analysis of open chromatin regions 298 revealed discrete peaks in the ACE2 locus, with the highest signal detected in proximal tubule 299 cells S1 and S3, which are also the highest ACE2-expressing cells (Fig. 5D ). Our approach failed 300 to detect significant signal enrichment in the ACE2 locus in endothelial cells, possibly related 301 to the low level of expression (Fig. 5D) . Within the cells of the kidney we observed the highest 302 percentage of ACE2 + cells in the proximal tubule S3, with a lower percentage in the proximal 303 tubule S1 and endothelial cells (Fig. 5E)
body_text.section: Epigenetic regulation of ACE2 in each cell subtype of the monkey kidney 288

body_text.text: ACE2 + cells demonstrated that these regions were preferentially enriched in signal transducer 305 and activator of transcription 1 and 3 (STAT1 and 3) and interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF1) 306 binding sites (Fig. 5F ). These findings suggested that tissue protective cytokines including IL5, 307 IL6, EGF and interferons are acting on these proximal tubule cells S3 to induce ACE2. We 308 focused on IL6 because a recent clinical trial has been started that uses anti-IL6 receptor (IL6R) 309 antibodies in the treatment of COVID-19 310 (http://www.chictr.org.cn/showprojen.aspx?proj=49409). IL6 is a potent regulator of 311 immune responses and can be produced by a variety of interstitial cells including fibroblasts, 312 endothelial cells and more importantly tissue macrophages (Heinrich et al., 1990) . 313

body_text.text: Interestingly, we also noticed that distribution of IL6R correlated well with ACE2 in proximal 314 tubule cells (Fig. 5G, Supplemental Fig. S5D ). In human kidney a similar co-expression pattern 315 was detected (Fig. 5H) . 316
body_text.section: . Motif analysis within the open chromatin regions in 304

body_text.text: Our observations suggest a potential positive feedback loop between IL6 and ACE2 expression 317 that can exacerbate COVID-19 disease progression due to increased viral entry and 318 dissemination. 319 In this study, we have generated a single-cell transcriptomic atlas of nine organs (liver, kidney, 331 lung, pancreas, neocortex, aorta, parotic gland, thyroid and peripheral blood) from 332 cynomolgus monkey. We used this dataset not only to provide fundamental information 333 about the cellular composition of the different tissues tested but also as a platform to dissect 334 the overall expression distribution of the SARS-CoV-2 entry receptor, ACE2, and its serine available human single-cell RNA-seq data, we have also uncovered significant differences 342 between human and monkey. We showed different expression patterns for ACE2 in the lung, 343

body_text.text: where the highest levels were detected in ciliated cells in monkey and pulmonary alveolar 344 type 2 cells in human. Similarly, we observed marked differences in liver, in which monkey 345 hepatocytes displayed higher ACE2 and a larger number of positive cells compared to the 346 human. We do not know whether these differences will affect the pathogenesis of COVID-19 347 between these two species. Nevertheless, this is a relevant finding considering that monkeys reactions to SARS-CoV-2 infection (Fig. 6) Breeding Centre (Guangzhou, China). The monkey was anesthetized with ketamine 398 hydrochloride (10 mg/kg) and barbiturate (40 mg/kg) administration before being euthanized 399 by exsanguination. Tissues were isolated and placed on the ice-cold board for dissection. 400

body_text.text: Whole organs including lung, kidney, pancreas, liver, brain, thyroid, parotid gland, and aorta 401 were cut into 5-10 pieces, respectively (50-200 mg/piece). Samples were then quickly frozen 402 in liquid nitrogen and stored until nuclear extraction was performed. PBMC were isolated 403 from heparinized venous blood using a Lymphoprep TM medium (STEMCELL Technologies, The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.022103 doi: bioRxiv preprint 18 Cells with low fragments (<1000) and TSS proportion (<0.1) were removed. Then, filtered data 484 were imported into R and the dimensionality was reduced by latent semantic indexing. 485

FIGREF0.text: 249 on the expression of SLC5A2 and SLC7A13 (Lee et al., 2015) (Supplemental table 2B, Fig. S4). 250 These two genes are sodium and glucose cotransporters involved in glucose reabsorption in 251 the kidney (Santer and Calado, 2010; Yu et al., 2011). We did not include thyroid, pancreas or 252 aorta in these analyses because of lack of high-quality available human single-cell datasets. 253As for the neocortex and PBMC, they have little to no expression of ACE2 in human (

FIGREF1.text: 267 highest correlation was observed for transmembrane protein 27 (TMEM27, cor = 0.84), a 268 protein involved in trafficking amino acid transporters to the apical brush border of kidney 269 proximal tubules (Chu et al., 2017). This is unsurprising considering that TMEM27 is an 270 important paralog of ACE2, and high expression was restricted to kidney cells. DnaJ heat shock 271 protein family (Hsp40) member C12 (DNAJC12, cor = 0.78), a gene with a role in immune 272 response processes (Sigdel et al., 2013), had a distribution like TMEM27. Importantly, we also 273 observed high correlation with Indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 2 (IDO2, cor = 0.77), a gene with 274 abundant expression in kidney and liver cells that was also expressed in the lung and other 275 organs. IDO2 has been shown to function during the early phases of immune responses and 276

FIGREF2.text: 281 These data highlight potential therapeutic targets to help in the fight against SARS-CoV-2. Due 282 to their potential co-regulation with ACE2, DNAJC12 and ANPEP it is possible that they 283 modulate, or are directly involved in viral entry. Alternatively, depletion of cells expressing 284 IDO2 and ANPEP, through a cytopathic effect of the virus, could trigger an uncontrolled 285 immune response and contribute to the immune cell exhaustion observed in COVID-19 (Guo 286 et al., 2020). 287

FIGREF3.text: and organs are composed of many different cell types that can vary in 322 abundance and cell state. Tissue heterogeneity is only beginning to be unraveled thanks to 323 the advent of single-cell profiling technologies that allow us to precisely map transcriptomic 324 and epigenomic programs. These technologies are revolutionizing our view of human 325 physiology and disease. Great efforts are being made to generate the first version of both 326 human and murine atlases (Han et al., 2018; Han et al., 2020); the mouse is among the most 327 commonly used model organisms in biomedical research, but many developmental or 328 pathological aspects are not paralleled in human. Understanding tissue and organ complexity 329in species that are phylogenetically close to humans is an unmet requirement. 330

FIGREF4.text: 335 protease coactivator TMPRSS2 (Hoffmann et al., 2020; Walls et al., 2020). Interestingly, ACE2 336 was expressed in multiple epithelial tissues besides the lung, specifically the kidney, liver and 337 thyroid. Other organs of epithelial origin such as the gut have also been implicated in the 338 pathogenesis of the disease (Ong et al., 2020). A consequence of this is that the SARS2-CoV-339 2 virus could infect these organs too, which would explain some of the reported clinical 340 manifestations of COVID-19 (Zhu et al., 2020). By comparing our dataset with publicly 341

FIGREF5.text: 348 are a preferred model for studying the effectiveness of drug treatments and of vaccines 349 against the impending COVID-19 pandemic. 350 are involved in stimulating different types of immune responses. We observed 353 high expression of IDO2 and ANPEP in kidney, liver and lung. Expression of these can be 354 further induced by viral infection and have been reported to be immune modulators and/or 355 mediate viral entry (Ball et al., 2009; Delmas et al., 1992). These observations are relevant as 356 they highlight new potential therapeutic vulnerabilities in the current emergency. In this 357 respect, a number of inhibitors of ANPEP are currently being developed and could serve to 358 prevent the immune cell exhaustion often observed in many severe COVID-19 cases (Zheng 359 et al., 2020). Similarly, mesenchymal stem/stroma cells (MSC) have immunomodulatory 360 functions that are partly related to IDO2 production (Ball et al., 2009). It is tempting to 361 speculate that cell therapies based on MSC could ameliorate COVID-19 by normalizing 362 immune function and preventing cytokine storms (Wilson et al., 2015). 363 Intriguingly, in our data, we see heterogenous expression of ACE2 within the individual cell 364 subtypes in six out of the nine monkey organs that we analyzed, which is also observed in the 365 three human organs analyzed. Interestingly, we noticed two different cell populations in the 366 kidney proximal tubule, one with higher ACE2 expression than the other. We performed 367 single-cell ATAC-seq of this organ to understand whether this phenomenon has an epigenetic 368 basis. Analysis of open chromatin regions within the ACE2 locus revealed the enrichment of 369 STAT1, STAT3 and IRF1 binding sites. These transcription factors have important immune 370 functions and are direct targets of tissue protective and innate immune responses such as 371 interleukin-6 signaling pathway and interferons. Analysis of IL6R distribution showed broad 372 expression within different the ACE2 + organs in monkey and human. This suggests a link 373 between paracrine IL6 (e.g. secreted by stromal cells including tissue resident macrophages) 374 and enhanced ACE2 expression across different organs. Higher and more widespread ACE2 375 expression could promote increased viral entry. This observation could be of the utmost 376 importance given recent reports describing clinical trials with Tocilizumab, a monoclonal 377 antibody used for IL6R blockade in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (Villiger et al., 2016), for 378 the treatment of COVID-19 (http://www.chictr.org.cn/showprojen.aspx?proj=49409). IL6 has 379 been related to aging and tissue damage (Mosteiro et al., 2018), and this may explain why 380 elderly individuals and those with underlying inflammatory conditions have more severe 381

FIGREF6.text: 404 #07851) according to standard density gradient centrifugation methods. PBMC were 405 resuspended in 90% FBS, 10% DMSO (Sigma Aldrich, #D2650) freezing media and frozen using 406 a Nalgene® Mr. Frosty® Cryo 1°C Freezing Container (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #5100-0001) 407 in a -80°C freezer for 24 hours before being transferred to liquid nitrogen for long-term 408 storage. 409 410 Single-nucleus/cell suspension preparation 411We isolated nuclei as previously described(Bakken et al., 2018). Briefly, tissues were thawed, 412 minced and added to lysis buffer. Lysates were filtered and resuspended in cell resuspension 413 buffer. Frozen PBMC vials were rapidly thawed in a 37°C water bath for ~2 minutes, then 414 quenched with 10 ml 37°C pre-warmed 1X phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, Thermo 415Fisher Scientific, #10010031) supplemented with 10% FBS. PBMCs were centrifuged at 500 416 R.C.F. for 5 minutes at room temperature. The supernatant was removed, and the cell 417 pellet was resuspended in 3 ml 37°C pre-warmed 1X PBS containing 0.04% bovine serum 418 albumin (BSA, Sangon Biotech, A600903), passed through a 40 μm cell strainer (Falcon, 419 #352340) and then centrifuged at 500 R.C.F. for 5 minutes at room temperature. Nuclei or 420 C Series Single-Cell Library Prep Set (MGI, #1000021082) was utilized as 425 previously described (Liu et al. 2019). In brief, single-nucleus/cell suspensions were used for 426 droplet generation, emulsion breakage, beads collection, reverse transcription, and cDNA 427 amplification to generate barcoded libraries. Indexed single-cell RNA-seq libraries were 428 constructed according to the manufacturer's protocol. The sequencing libraries were 429 quantified by Qubit™ ssDNA Assay Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #Q10212). Single-cell ATAC-430 seq libraries were prepared using DNBelab C4 Single-Cell ATAC-seq Library Prep Set (MGI). 431 DNA nanoballs (DNBs) were loaded into the patterned Nano arrays and sequenced on the 432 ultra-high-throughput DIPSEQ T1 sequencer using the following read length: 30 bp for read 1, 433 inclusive of 10 bp cell barcode 1, 10 bp cell barcode 2 and 10 bp unique molecular identifier 434 (UMI), 100 bp of transcript sequence for read 2, and 10 bp for sample index. 435 436 Single-cell RNA-seq data processing 437 Raw sequencing reads from DIPSEQ-T1 were filtered and demultiplexed using PISA (version 438 0.2) (https://github.com/shiquan/PISA). Reads were aligned to Macaca_fascicularis_5.0 439 genome using STAR (version 2.7.4a) (Dobin et al., 2013) and sorted by sambamba (version 440 0.7.0) (Tarasov et al., 2015). Cell versus gene UMI count matrix was generated with PISA. 441 442 Cell clustering and identification of cell types 443 Clustering analysis of the complete cynomolgus monkey tissue dataset was performed using 444 Scanpy (version 1.4) (Wolf et al., 2018) in a Python environment. Parameters used in each 445 function were manually curated to portray the optimal clustering of cells. In preprocessing, 446 cells or nuclei were filtered based on the criteria of expressing a minimum of 200 genes and 447 a gene which is expressed by a minimum of 3 cells or nuclei. Filtered data were ln (counts per 448 million (CPM)/100 + 1) transformed. 3000 highly variable genes were selected according to 449 their average expression and dispersion. The number of UMI and the percentage of 450 mitochondrial gene content were regressed out and each gene was scaled by default options. 451 Dimension reduction starts with principal component analysis (PCA), and the number of 452 dataset was portrayed using the Seurat package (version 3.1.1) (Stuart et al., 2019) 458 in R environment by default parameters for filtering, data normalization, dimensionality 459 reduction, clustering, and gene differential expression analysis. Finally, we annotated each 460 cell type by extensive literature reading and searching for the specific gene correlation and Gene Ontology (GO) term enrichment analysis 464 The correlation between ACE2 and other genes was drawn using Pearson correlation 465 coefficient (PCC) with gene expression value merged from cells of the same cell types with 466 the R package psych (version 1.9.12.31). To infer the biological function of highly correlated 467 genes (cor > 0.6 and adjusted P value < 0.001), we performed gene set enrichment analysis 468 using Metascape (https://metascape.org/gp/index.html). 469 470 Differential gene expression analysis 471 Differential expression analysis between proximal tubule S1 and proximal tubule S3 was 472 performed using the FindMarkers function of the Seurat package (version 3.1.1). 473 474 Single-cell ATAC-seq data processing 475 Raw sequencing reads from DIPSEQ-T1 were filtered and demultiplexed using PISA (version 476 0.2) (https://github.com/shiquan/PISA). Peak calling was performed using MACS2 (version 477 2.1.2) (Feng et al., 2012) with options -f BAM -B -q 0.01 -nomodel. The cell versus peak reads 478 count matrix was generated by custom script. To create a gene activity matrix, we extracted 479 gene coordinates for cynomolgus monkey from NCBI, and extended them to ±2 kb region 480 around TSS. The gene activity score matrix was calculated by custom script. 481 482 Single-cell ATAC-seq cell clustering and cell type identification 483

The sequences 493 were imported into R and were matched with all Homo sapiens motifs form JASPAR2018 using 494 matchMotifs function in motifmatchr packages version 1.8.0 with default parameter. 495 496 Human single-cell RNA-seq datasets 497 All human single-cell RNA-seq data matrix were obtained from publicly available dataset as 498 described: (1) Kidney data from Stewart et al. was download from 499 https://www.kidneycellatlas.org/ (Stewart et al., 2019); (2) Lung data from Madissoon et al. 500 was download from https://www.tissuestabilitycellatlas.org/ (Madissoon et al., 2019); (3) 501 Liver data from Aizarani et al. was download from GEO at accession GSE124395 (used for processing the single-cell RNA-seq and single-cell ATAC-L., M.A.E., Y.H. and X.X. conceived the idea. L.L., L.H., Y.L., S.L., X.W. and Y.Yuan. designed 527 the experiment. L.H., Y.L., S.L., X.W., Y.Y., M.C. and C.W.W. collected the tissue samples. C.L., 528 Z.W., Y.Yuan, Y. Yu, M.W., T.W., Y.L., C.W., Y.Z., T.T., Y.H., H.L., L.X., J.X. and M.C. performed 529 the experiments. P.H.M provided critical 531 review of the manuscript. M.A.E., G.V., C.W., Y.L. and L.L. wrote the manuscript with input 532 from all authors. X.X., Y.H., L.L. and M.A.E supervised the entire study. All other authors 533 contributed to the work. All authors read and approved the manuscript for submission. Kidney proximal tubule cells within the nephron have the highest expression 595 of ACE2 receptor which facilitates virus entry. After virus contact, IL6R stimulates an immune 596 response that, through the activation of STATs factors, potentiates the paracrine positive 597 feedback loop that facilitates virus spreading. IL6 expression, which is higher in elderly 598 patients and those with inflammatory conditions, is effectively targeted by anti-IL6R 599 monoclonal antibodies leading to a more favourable disease course. TABREF0.text: , 2E, 3A lower panel, 3C lower panel). 222 Therefore, our data show that ACE2 and TMPRSS2 are expressed in a variety of cell types, 223 mainly epithelial cells, within the nine monkey organs/tissues (Supplemental table 2A). They 224 also suggest that variations in cell state (e.g. differentiation state, stimulation state or 225 topographical distribution) cause heterogenous expression across an individual tissue. These 226 observations may provide important clues about COVID-19 pathogenesis and 227 Comparative analysis of ACE2 and TMPRSS2 expression in human and non-human primate 230

TABREF1.text: . Importantly, high IL6 levels have been detected in 382 14 plasma from COVID-19 patients (Wan et al., 2020). The proposed enhanced affinity of SARS-383 CoV-2 for ACE2 compared to SARS-CoV may underlie the differences in the clinical course 384 between the two diseases (Shang et al., 2020). 385 All these observations revealed new potential mechanisms for COVID-19, opening new 386 therapeutic avenues for disease management.
